pullRequest.body:
Docstrings which assume you are reading them from the file they are defined in are completely useless on hover.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [0cefb33b17](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/23123/commits/0cefb33b1778ec7491b0cadab0bfbc659ae2db7b)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

No declarations were harmed in the making of this PR! üêô
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
Second pass was a huge improvement!
I'd say we should keep this part: the implementation details are useful but the mathematical details should stay too
I don't think it's helpful (or even accurate) to say it's equipped with a metric, the whole point is that `dist` doesn't need to satisfy all the axioms a metric does
More generally, I prefer the first sentence of the older one: knowing that a pseudometric space is a space with a distance is more useful to read than that it's a topological space

```suggestion
/-- A pseudometric space is a topological space and uniform space equipped with a metric `dist`,
```
and everywhere else in the new docstrings
I am not sure I agree here
It does seem like "pseudometric" is used far more than "pseudo metric" is, informally speaking.

```suggestion
/-- A metric space is a `PseudoMetricSpace` which additionally satisfies the axiom `dist x y = 0 ‚Üí x = y`. 
As a consequence, it is a T1 topological space and a uniform space, where the topology comes from the 
metric.
```
see, eg, the docstring for `Group`.

I disagree here. I think of the `Group` as precisely an example of a bad docstring: I want to know what a group without first needing to know what a monoid is! (and four years ago, when I was learning about groups and monoids, I found this docstring particularly unhelpful).

Here specifically a `PseudoMetricSpace` is just the data of a distance satisfying the triangle inequality, so I really don't see the point

In that case, starting the sentence with T1 topological space and uniform space is even worse, surely, it requires the user to know three new things, all of which are typically taught *after* metric spaces. Saying it's a distance satisfying the triangle inequality would be fine by me too. (edit: I wrote this before seeing your update, I'm now satisfied about this point)
I don't think this is helpful here: at this point there's not even an expectation that the uniformity fields would be necessary!
Hmm... that part I took from the existing docstrings
This is similarly not accurate: there might not be an extended metric which produces this. More generally, the mathematical content of the class should certainly be mentioned here!
This version I like a lot more now. Let's mention the other two axioms too, otherwise it seems like it's only the triangle inequality needed.
I think we should also actually write what the triangle inequality is!

```suggestion
Note that a T1 pseudo extended metric space is just an extended metric space (`EMetricSpace`).
```
Similarly above, it could be nice to reference the other classes in a linkable way.
It's already referenced in the paragraph just above, which is why I didn't link to it here again
Probably a good idea to keep a reference to the `[forgetful inheritance]` library note.

```suggestion
See `PseudoEMetricSpace` for the similar class with the `edist x y = 0 ‚Üî x = y` assumption
weakened to `edist x x = 0`.
```

```suggestion
See `PseudoMetricSpace` for the similar class with the `dist x y = 0 ‚Üî x = y` assumption
weakened to `dist x x = 0`.
```
adjust line wrapping?

Some people around here like semantic line-wrapping. Although I don't really like it, this feels like a prime example where non-semantic line-wrapping won't gain you any line over semantic line-wrapping

pullRequest.title: doc: provide an actual docstring to `MetricSpace`
